importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The crash occurred in September 2025, and the interim report was published in October 2025, placing the event within a recent timeframe that continues to receive public and governmental attention.

keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet safety specifications and was not certified to carry passengers.
The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, leading to a derailment and subsequent crash that killed at least 16 people and injured others.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance practices, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant even though it was not properly implemented.
The funicular operator, CARRIS, approved the maintenance plan as compliant, which may have contributed to safety lapses.
The interim report is preliminary and not conclusive; a final report will be released next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly funicular crash in Lisbon's Glória funicular in September 2025 resulted in at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped mid-journey on Calçada da Glória. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet safety specifications set by the operator CARRIS and that maintenance tasks were incorrectly recorded as completed, despite not being properly performed. Eyewitnesses described the derailment as chaotic and sudden, with one man, Bruno, recalling the scene as 'a toy being thrown' across the street. The interim report is not conclusive, and a final report is expected next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
